Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Story:
I was on my lunch break at the construction site, boots caked in dust, when my phone buzzed. It was Sam, my old friend, sounding frazzled. He’d just moved into his new apartment and was knee-deep in flat-pack chaos. “Can you hop on a quick video call? These instructions make no sense,” he texted. I could almost hear the frustration in his words. As a friend, I knew he counted on me, especially since he didn’t have anyone else nearby to help.

But just as I was about to reply, my foreman walked by, pinning up a notice about an optional training session next week. “We need more guys certified for the new equipment,” he said, glancing at me. I knew what that meant—if I wanted to keep up with the team and maybe get more hours, I should be there. My mind spun. Sam needed me now, but the crew expected me to step up, too. I stared at my phone, torn between being the friend Sam could rely on and the worker my team needed. My thumb hovered over the screen, heart pounding, caught between two worlds.
